Hi folks,

I'm enjoying using junit's various assertXxx() methods.

In my application we have lots of java.math.BigDecimal numbers. As you may
know, the BigDecimal.equals() method considers two numbers to be different
even if they differ only in their scale. In other words 12.30 does not equal
12.300. I would like to write tests in which I consider such numbers to be
close enough.

The BigDecimal class provides a compareTo() method which returns 0 to
indicate that two numbers are "close enough" in the sense I mean. So, one
thing I could do is just write my tests as:

   assert(a.compareTo(b) == 0);

But I'm wondering if there is an elegant and/or easy way to define some
assertEquals() method(s) that take BigDecimal arguments and do what I want.

Should I extend TestCase (calling it, say, MyTestCase), add those methods,
and then make all my tests extend MyTestCase? I'm not quite sure I see where
to insert this into the class hierarchy.

Thanks.
- Alan Bram
